awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: Collaborative Research: IA: Large-Scale Multi-Parameter Analysis of Honeybee Behavior in their Natural Habitat
awd_abstract_narration:
Honey bees exhibit highly complex behavior and are vital for our agriculture. Due to the rich social organization of bees, the overall performance and health of a bee colony depends both on a successful division of labor among the bees and on adequate reaction to the environment, which involves complex behavioral patterns and biological mechanisms. Much remains to be discovered on these matters as research is currently limited by our ability to effectively collect and analyze individual's behavior at large scale, out of the laboratory. The technology developed in this project will enable biologists to study the individual behavior of thousands of bees over extended periods of time. It builds on innovative algorithms and software to analyze big data collected from colonies in the field. Study of behavioral patterns at such scale will provide unique information to advance knowledge on biological processes such as circadian rhythms that influence bee behavior in addition to playing an important role in animals and humans. The models developed will help better understand factors involved in colony collapse disorder, thus guiding future research on threats to such an important pollinator. This work will be performed through the tight collaboration of a multi-disciplinary team of researchers to combine the latest advances in computer science and data science with expertise in biology.  It will provide the opportunity to train students from underrepresented minority on research at the intersection of these fields and to reach more than 600 undergraduate students, high school students, and the general public about how the Big Data approach can contribute to current scientific and ecological challenges.

The project will develop a platform for the high-throughput analysis of individual insect behaviors and gain new insights into the role of individual variations of behavior on bee colony performance. Joint video and sensor data acquisition will monitor marked individuals at multiple colonies over large continuous periods, generating the first datasets of bee activities of this kind on such a scale. Algorithms and software will be developed to take advantage of a High Performance Computing facility to perform the analysis of these massive datasets. Semi-supervised machine learning will leverage the large amount of data available to facilitate the creation of new detectors for parameters such as pollen carrying bees or fanning behavior, currently annotated manually. Predictive models and functional data analysis methods will be developed to find patterns in individual behavior based on multiple parameters and over large temporal scales. These advances are expected to help uncover mechanisms of individual variations previously unobservable. They will enable the first large scale biological study on the circadian rhythms of the bee based on the variations in behavior of individuals in multiple activities instead of reasoning on single activities or averages. Progress, datasets and software will be shared with the community on the project website (sites.google.com/a/upr.edu/bigdbee).

por.por_cntn:
In this project, a collaborative effort supported by National Science Foundation awards #1707355 and #1633184, we developed new methods for the study of the behavior of honey bees based on extensive video and sensor data collection and their computational analysis. Honey bees are insects with highly complex behaviors that are vital for human activity in agriculture. The developed methods led to new insights into (1) the response of the colony to its environment in normal and stress conditions, which is responsible for its performance and its health, and (2) the biological processes such as circadian rhythms, which regulate their individual behavior, and are shared by animals and humans.

Intellectual merit:

We created the LabelBee system for the collection, annotation and analysis of honey bee behavior from video and sensor monitoring. It provides advanced artificial intelligence and visualization capabilities to facilitate the analysis of large video datasets necessary for the discovery of complex behavior patterns. By integrating powerful deep learning techniques, we were able to detect individual honey bees reliably and extract precise information such as the position of their body parts and the presence of pollen balls. This allowed us to monitor the colony ramp to detect entrances, exits and pollen entry in a fully automatic way. The final system can track all bees to provide global information about colony health and foraging of ressources, as well as identify bees marked with a lightweight barcode tag for a detailed analysis of their individual behavior. It constitutes a proof-of-concept capable of analyzing the videos without manual intervention at large-scale in a cloud server environment. This work opened the way for an extended system suitable for real-time pollinator monitoring in the field, which we are currently developing in a follow-up grant supported by the US Department of Agriculture.

Extensive video and sensor data was collected from a colony over an entire year, as well as a month of simultaneous capture at 10 colonies. A dataset of 1550 images for the detection of pollen bearing bees was shared with the community. The continuous video and sensor recordings throughout 2017 and 2018 provided a unique dataset covering periods before and after the impact of category 5 hurricane Maria that caused a massive vegetation loss. Its analysis led to important discoveries related to the colony response to such lack of resources: first, it triggered a higher production of "wintering bees" by the colony, which are individuals characterized by a 3-4 fold lifespan extension and increased hypopharyngeal gland size among other changes and, second, the lack of fresh pollen entry was shown to be a key signal triggering cannibalism of young larvae.

We also developed software to analyze the circadian rhythms that characterize the temporal patterns of each individual, and classify them. Based on the temporal activity patterns of individual foragers in controlled conditions, several findings were made on the importance of the circadian rhythms and its interaction with various antibiotics, neonicotinoid pesticides, drone mating flights and the memory mechanisms. Based on sensor data in the colony, we made several discoveries relating the synchronization and development of the circadian clock and temperature oscillations in different parts of the colony. The tools developed to analyze the circadian rhythm were also applied to a wide range of solitary and social insects as well as to humans, which suggested interesting new research questions on the role of biological clocks in social organization.

Broader impact:

This project led to 21 peer-reviewed publications, 6 graduate student dissertations, and 68 presentations in local, national and international conferences. More than 19,000 hours of video and sensor recordings were collected, and 5 software tools were developed and open-sourced. In terms of training, it provided research and professional development opportunities to a total of 66 students of which 20 were graduate students and 46 were undergraduates. They gained first-hand experience in multi-disciplinary research at the convergence of computer science, data science and biology, and are better prepared to join the workforce with skills to harness the data revolution. It is important to mention that almost all the students trained were from underrepresented minorities (hispanics) and included 28 women. A total of 23 outreach activities targeting pre-school, middle and high school students as well as undergraduates, beekeepers and the general public were performed, and directly impacted approximately 1,690 persons. The activities of our team were widely disseminated in social media, which included 9 newspaper articles, 2 TV interviews and 1 Radio interview.
